definition:
Let $a_k$ and $b_k$ be two sequences of real or complex numbers for
$k \in {\mathbb N}_0$ ( ${\mathbb N}_0$ is the set of natural numbers
containing zero). The Cauchy product is defined by:
$$(a \circ b)(k) = \sum_{l=0}^k a_l b_{k-l}.$$ This is basically the
convolution for two sequences. Therefore the product of two series
$\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} a_k$, $\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} b_k$ is given by:
$$\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_k = \left(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} a_k \right)\cdot \left(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} b_k \right) =
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \sum_{l=0}^k a_l b_{k-l}.$$ A sufficient condition
for the resulting series $\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_k$ to be absolutely
convergent is that $\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} a_k$ and
$\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} b_k$ both converge absolutely .
